conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the coil.
The EMF induced in a rotating coil in a magnetic field is given by the formula: \( \mathcal{E} = n B A \omega \sin(\omega t) \).
Definitions of variables: \( n \) is the number of turns, \( B \) is the magnetic induction intensity, \( A \) is the area of the coil, \( \omega \) is the angular velocity, \( t \) is the time.
Calculate the area \( A \) of the rectangular coil: \( A = l_{AB} \cdot l_{BC} = 0.2 \mathrm{m} \cdot 0.5 \mathrm{m} = 0.1 \mathrm{m}^2 \).
Given values: magnetic induction intensity \( B = 0.1 \mathrm{T} \), number of turns \( n = 100 \), angular velocity \( \omega = 100\pi \mathrm{rad/s} \).
Substitute values into the EMF formula: \( \mathcal{E} = 100 \cdot 0.1 \cdot 0.1 \cdot 100\pi \cdot \sin(\omega t) = 100\pi \sin(\omega t) \).
Timing starts when the coil plane passes through the neutral plane, initial angle \( \theta = 0 \).
The maximum value of the sine function is 1, so the maximum EMF is \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = 100\pi \cdot 1 = 100\pi \mathrm{V} \).
The magnitude of the induced electromotive force in the coil is \( \boxed{100\pi \mathrm{V}} \).
